GetInsured Conducts First-Ever Minnesota Resident Survey and Retires More Than $1 Million of Consumer Medical Debt Across the State
By Paul Neutz|Tuesday, July 30, 2019
This summer, GetInsured conducted its first-ever Medical Debt Survey in the state of Minnesota. The company did this to better understand the medical debt situation in Minnesota, and how ordinary residents are dealing with it. As it turns out, in Minnesota, as in other states across America, medical debt is a big problem. An individual or a family with medical debt can face tremendous consequences  many will be driven into poverty, as a result.

The company did this to better understand the medical debt situation in Minnesota, and how ordinary residents are dealing with it. As it turns out, in Minnesota, as in other states across America, medical debt is a big problem. An individual or a family with medical debt can face tremendous consequences  many will be driven into poverty, as a result.
One of the most important facts we uncovered from the survey is that nearly 60 percent of respondents reported receiving a medical bill that came as a surprise or was difficult to pay. And 87 percent of respondents are at least somewhat concerned about high medical bills in the future.
One of the most important facts we uncovered from the survey is that nearly 60 percent of respondents reported receiving a medical bill that came as a surprise or was difficult to pay. And 87 percent of respondents are at least somewhat concerned about high medical bills in the future.
In fact, in order to pay for unexpected or high medical bills, Minnesotans surveyed cited general savings (45 percent), vacation / recreation (36 percent), grocery spending (28 percent) and even retirement savings (20 percent) as areas where they needed to cut back. These individuals and families are experiencing financial strain, due to the increasing cost burden of the high cost of health care.

To alleviate those Minnesotans facing severe financial hardship due to health care costs, GetInsured was able to retire $1,065,587 of medical debt in Minnesota through a contribution to RIP Medical Debt, a nonprofit 501(c)(3) charity that locates, buys and forgives medical debt on behalf of donors. Earlier this year, GetInsured retired nearly $2 million of medical debt in California.
